newsitem.title: GREECE: Greece vows to trip EU-Turkish relations at summit.
newsitem.headline: Greece vows to trip EU-Turkish relations at summit.

text.p: Greece will object to any efforts to bring Turkey closer to the European Union during the European Council in Dublin in December, Foreign Minister Theodoros Pangalos said on Thursday.
Blasting Turkey for its human rights record and perceived aggression against Greece, the outspoken minister asked for international military and economic measures against Ankara.

"We must find ways to convince Turkey to behave normally in the international community; military and economic measures that will force Turkey to behave in a civilised manner to its neighbours and its people," Pangalos told a news conference.
Greece, which has long been at odds with Turkey over territorial and minority rights issues, often points to Ankara's poor human rights record.

On Wednesday the London-based Amnesty International human rights group condemned Turkey for the alleged torture of children held in custody. Ankara rejected the allegations and said Amnesty was part of a campaign to sully Turkey's image internationally.
Diplomatic sources said Pangalos was raising his objections ahead of an upcoming report by the EU's Irish presidency that is expected to call for closer EU-Turkish ties.
"Human rights (violations) and genocide are international crimes," Pangalos said. "No government has the right to butcher and torture its people."
He said that under the latest human rights report it would be a contradiction for the EU to hold meetings with Turkish officials during the summit.
"We consider calling any such meetings a paradox," he said. "Not everything is well between the EU and Turkey."
Greece also objects to a lunch planned by the Irish presidency for Turkey's Islamist Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan on the sidelines of the summit.
"We will be represented at the appropriate level," Pangalos said. Diplomatic sources said that meant a junior goverment official would attend the lunch to counter Turkey's positions.
Greek and Turkish rivalry spilled over into the Western European Union (WEU), the European Union's fledgling defence arm, on Tuesday, threatening the group's international aid missions.
Turkish Foreign Minister Tansu Ciller warned that Ankara would block the use of NATO equipment by the WEU because of Greek objections to giving Ankara a strong say in WEU mission planning.
The two countries, despite being NATO allies, almost came to war earlier this year over uninhabited islets in the Aegean. The United States stepped in to broker a deal easing the tension.
